subject: Re: [junit] Reporting more then 1 failed assertion per test
msgSnippet: ... The following example demonstrates what I mean. I think it is concise and focused and, in addition, it clearly demonstrates the behavior of the method
messageBody:
Mike Duffy wrote:

> I think it is best to keep methods as concise and as focused as
> possible. ... For me, this means writing several small test methods for the
> method I am testing, and at mosthaving one assert per test method and
> sometimes no asserts at all.

The following example demonstrates what I mean. I think it is concise and
focused and, in addition, it clearly demonstrates the behavior of the method
being tested. I can also see at a glance whether I have tested everything.
The field testObject is initialized in setUp().

public void testGetIcon()
{
Icon icon = testObject.getIcon(ViewObject.SMALL_ICON);
assertTrue("SMALL_ICON must return a small (16x16) icon",
icon.getIconWidth() == 16 && icon.getIconHeight() == 16);

icon = testObject.getIcon(ViewObject.BIG_ICON);
assertTrue("BIG_ICON must return a big (32x32) icon",
icon.getIconWidth() == 32 && icon.getIconHeight() == 32);

try {
testObject.getIcon(ViewObject.SELECTED_BIG_ICON);
fail("other variants must throw an IllegalArgumentException");
} catch (IllegalArgumentException success) {
// OK (or assertTrue(true) if we were counting asserts
}

try {
testObject.getIcon(0);
fail("a null parameter must throw a NullPointerException");
} catch (NullPointerException success) {
// OK (ditto)
}
}

Isn't that better than 4 little methods?

- Tom
